title: Noderann's Journey
body:
Transcript

With grasses pure as emerald,

In sunlight of splendid gold,

Of rivers like flowing diamonds,


Was Edrenine’s lands made,

And in the city of Naustaun,

Was the god’s great statue laid.


Norderann gazed with eyes of wonder,

To the hills and birds and beasts,

And knew his maker’s work to be complete.                                    


“Oh father,” he said, “our lands are splendid,

Like none before it alike,

A verse of equal beauty no hand could surely write.


Why then do the Dommahounds,

In their dark and loveless ways,

Shun this resplendent beauty?”


“Norderann, my son,” said Oberann the old,

Who was as wise as wisdom comes,

A man who leant his ear as readily he did his tongue.


“My son, those maleficent brutes,

Live in perpetual night,

And love it as if it were light.


“No kindness nor pureness,

No tenderness nor holiness,

Are found in their blackened lands.”


The youthful son knew not,

Of knowledge learned by living,

And the truth he did not see.


An oath he vowed to Oberann,

To find the hidden good,

In those who dwelt in darkness.


“No, my son, it is a folly,

To think that they will agree,

That pastures green are heavenly.


Their earth is rotten,

Their souls are poisoned waters,

Do not waste your care on them.”


But Norderann was stubborn,

And set off down path and trail,

Cut through golden fields.


He reached the gate of Arangarn,

And left the Erman City,

To seek those who lived for misery.


“Norderann, my friend,” cried a fellow,

Tall and wide and set like stone,

A companion indeed would Resta make.


“What journey follows,” he asked,

“To lake, mountain or to meadow?

Which road do you mean to take alone?”


“To show my father lies,

That wronged are those whom we despise,”

Said Norderann, in a voice firm and bold.


Resta cried, “Hark! Tell me no,

That you speak not of our ancient foe,

The wretched race of Dommahound!”


“Yes, that very same,” said Norderann,

“I see you begrudge them too,

But what malice have they ever done unto you?”


“To me, not one. But tales are told,

Of infernal temper, endless sorrow,

Deathly figures, where souls are hallowed.


I am strong, tall and broad,

But call me coward and I’ll show you a sword,

Call you not brave, I’d call you a fool.”


Norderann dismissed Resta’s caution,

And begun his journey along the cobbled street,

To unknown lands where borders meet.
preface: "Noderann's Journey" is a classical poem written about Noderann, an Erman, and his journey to the lands of the Dommahound - a journey that would restart an ancient conflict with the Erman enemy. Only a single extract of the first Canto (Chapter) survives.
